title: Ticket #1685: no documentation of specification of expression for -constraint option
description: On 8-11-2010, a condor-users post expresses frustration in generating a correct expression for use with condor_status -constraint. There are many references in the manual to condor_status, and a few to the section on ClassAds, but none explains the usage of single quote vs. double quote, and when backslashes might be appropriate as escape characters. More explanation and more examples within the condor_status manual page will help.
remarks:
2010-Sep-30 10:15:32 by smoler:
From Greg T: For most (all?) Unix shells, the single quote mark (') is a way to cause the command-line interpretation to not expand anything within single quote marks. Therefore, it becomes the right way to delimit a single expression that has white space characters which would otherwise cause the expression to be broken into multiple command-line arguments.

From TJ: Not so on Windows machines (old, normal command shell). A single quote mark would be passed through for the Condor tool to deal with. So, double quote marks are the right way on Windows to delimit a single expression with white space characters. Further gotcha is that an embedded (and needed) double quote mark must be escaped on Windows by using 2 consecutive double quote marks (""), whereas a Unix escape would be a backslash followed by a double quote mark (\").

Conclusion: virtually all our examples with the manual are Unix-specific.
